{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3307095,"name":"Poyraz AygÃ¼l","username":"poaygul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/poaygul/{size}/235100_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-11T18:10:30.173Z","cooked":"

We were building our robot today and were planning to test the moving arm. When we were building, we forgot to add washers and this is the result:

WhatsApp GÃ¶rsel 2024-02-11 saat 19.24.52_3b02d3041200Ã—1600 194 KB

WhatsApp GÃ¶rsel 2024-02-11 saat 19.36.49_94cfd7511500Ã—2000 231 KB

We were using REV MAXTubes and two 1:100 gearboxes with NEO 550s. It was supposed to have washers in the design, but when we were building, we forgot to add them.

You may want to look at a few other things as well to prevent this from happening, washers certainly will help -

Crushing Your MAXTube? Try These Spacers General Forum
Iâ€™m a huge fan of what REV has created with their 040 MAXTube. Itâ€™s lightweight and strong. The Thrifty 2 stage elevator I built using it weighs less than 20 pounds with gearboxes and motors, which is really pretty incredible. However, Iâ€™ve seen my students on 5010 and other examples of people just absolutely crushing it (quite literally.) Because the material is thin (like 1/16 wall tubing as well), itâ€™s really easy to overtighten thru bolts and bow your tube walls - Photo Credit @BryceHanson â€¦
REV Robotics

MAXTube Endcaps

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Price: USD 5

REV Robotics

MAXTube Internal Supports - 30 Pack

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Price: USD 18

You may also want to consider just using a thicker tube there as well if you have the weight -

The Thrifty Bot

Thrifty 2" x 1" Grid Pattern Aluminum Extrusion

Expand your robot's capabilities and build easier with the Thrifty Grid Pattern Aluminum Extrusion. Tubes are 47" long. Holes are 5mm (.197) in diameter with 1/2" grid spacing. Material is 6061 T-6 aluminum.

Price: USD 39.99

Try These Spacers","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":13}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":985,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"www.thethriftybot.com"},"post_url":"/t/dont-forget-washers/454346/2","custom_user_title":"www.thethriftybot.com","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":11},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":13,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3307104,"name":"Poyraz AygÃ¼l","username":"poaygul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/poaygul/{size}/235100_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-11T18:20:22.596Z","cooked":"

We currently canâ€™t get the pieces since weâ€™re from Turkey, but we will keep these in mind for next season! Any other suggestions that we can do with local supplies?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-02-11T18:20:22.596Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":645,"readers_count":644,"score":129.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":454346,"topic_slug":"dont-forget-washers","display_username":"Poyraz AygÃ¼l","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":985,"username":"Ryan_Dognaux","name":"Ryan Dognaux","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_dognaux/{size}/129138_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60521,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7840 Driver, Electrical, Strategy"},"post_url":"/t/dont-forget-washers/454346/3","custom_user_title":"7840 Driver, Electrical, Strategy","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3307108,"name":"","username":"DataChaos","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/71e660/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-02-11T18:21:51.326Z","cooked":"

We didnâ€™t have any tube supports and didnâ€™t 3D print spacers, so we just cut up some churros and placed them as supports in the tubing.

There actually were churros in the tubing, but not in that certain part

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-02-11T18:22:45.886Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":630,"readers_count":629,"score":131.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":454346,"topic_slug":"dont-forget-washers","display_username":"Poyraz AygÃ¼l","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":60239,"username":"DataChaos","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/71e660/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60521,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7840 Driver, Electrical, Strategy"},"post_url":"/t/dont-forget-washers/454346/5","custom_user_title":"7840 Driver, Electrical, Strategy","reactions":[{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3307117,"name":"Ryan Dognaux","username":"Ryan_Dognaux","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_dognaux/{size}/129138_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-11T18:27:49.727Z","cooked":"

The 3D printed spacer options posted above certainly will help fill the tube up to prevent crushing and using a larger washer should help as well.

It looks like from the video that you could fill the gap between this angled structure piece and the cross bar that pulled out. Maybe a 3D printed triangle block to fill the gap and help transfer some of the load into that part of the robot (or even a wood block cut to fit would work)

Screenshot_20240211-132523~2918Ã—920 62.7 KB

We will try this out tomorrow and come back with the results.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-02-11T18:32:12.269Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":551,"readers_count":550,"score":110.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":454346,"topic_slug":"dont-forget-washers","display_username":"Poyraz AygÃ¼l","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":985,"username":"Ryan_Dognaux","name":"Ryan Dognaux","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_dognaux/{size}/129138_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60521,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7840 Driver, Electrical, Strategy"},"post_url":"/t/dont-forget-washers/454346/7","custom_user_title":"7840 Driver, Electrical, Strategy","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3307350,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-12T00:18:04.346Z","cooked":"

Also, limit switches and/or S/W limits on the arm angle.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-02-12T00:18:04.346Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":483,"readers_count":482,"score":111.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":454346,"topic_slug":"dont-forget-washers","display_username":"Allen Nuttle","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14283,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/dont-forget-washers/454346/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3307351,"name":"","username":"AVHon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avhon/{size}/130071_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-12T00:20:23.407Z","cooked":"

And maybe ramp-up and ramp-down code to make the arm start and stop gently.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-02-12T00:20:23.407Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":478,"readers_count":477,"score":110.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":454346,"topic_slug":"dont-forget-washers","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":14283,"username":"nuttle","name":"Allen Nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41730,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"engineering mentor FRC 3494 & FTC 11329"},"post_url":"/t/dont-forget-washers/454346/9","custom_user_title":"engineering mentor FRC 3494 & FTC 11329","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3307355,"name":"","username":"Thor5090","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thor5090/{size}/226064_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-12T00:35:49.778Z","cooked":"
poaygul:

We were using REV MAXTubes

This didnâ€™t help your situation either. REV uses thin 0.040" material on the 1" ends of all their tubes. This isnâ€™t the reason it just didnâ€™t help things. Using 0.125" wall wouldâ€™ve helped but not solved the problem

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-02-12T00:35:49.778Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":466,"readers_count":465,"score":93.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":454346,"topic_slug":"dont-forget-washers","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53198,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"My views are mine and mine alone"},"post_url":"/t/dont-forget-washers/454346/10","custom_user_title":"My views are mine and mine alone","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3307360,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-12T00:59:26.623Z","cooked":"

Washers donâ€™t load spread very far. The failure here is from design issues. @Ryan_Dognaux covered the solutions nicely.

When doing big chain driven joints (or any big joints) it is imperative to have a direct compression/tension member between the axles, e.g. a plate with two bearings to lock the axles at the right distance apart.

Good luck!

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-02-12T00:59:26.623Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":420,"readers_count":419,"score":164.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":454346,"topic_slug":"dont-forget-washers","display_username":"JamesCH95","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3782,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/dont-forget-washers/454346/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3307362,"name":"Lexeo","username":"Lexeo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lexeo/{size}/160041_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-12T01:18:53.866Z","cooked":"

Screenshot_20240211-201334~21080Ã—1811 110 KB

We cnc cut some of these last season to reinforce tubing (and for field repair when that happened). You can add it inside our out.

You can even repair the existing tubing in a pinch.

A crush blocks is probably going to also be helpful, and there are some 3D printed designs for this already.

cad.onshape.com

This needs crush blocks, you can make them on a 3D printer, mill, CNC, hand drill and file or grinder. Whatever you have you can find a way to make crush blocks. I made some out of old bumper wood a few days ago.

By â€œDisaster Struck Againâ€ do you mean the tube crushing still shown in this picture?

I would read the recommendation on crush blocks above again. The ones sold by REV, or build your own by cutting a profile out of wood - the closer you make the crush block to the inner profile the better it will do at preventing this crushing action.

You can eliminate these structural failures by adding a load member between the two axles.

Currently it looks like the drive and shoulder sprocket are connected like thisâ€¦ leading to significant bending forces being resolved through the structure, including the tube segment that has failed again. The tension from the chain pulls the drive and shoulder together, bending the structure that holds them together.

Smiley face is bad.

If you add a member between the drive and shoulder, ideally one on each side, that will resolve the tension of the chain directly. The mounting of the drive and shoulder will have much less stress to deal with and youâ€™ll likely be in good shape.

This doesnâ€™t need to be fancy. A chunk of plastic plate with two holes would probably do the trick.

Two plates with some notches cut in them can be sandwiched around the axles, so no/limited disassembly required.

I know this works because Iâ€™ve had to do it before in a similar loading case on our 2018 (?) robot.
